secluded but not in the midst of the Saá¹ƒgha, or both in the midst of the Saá¹ƒgha and secluded, or neither in the midst of the Saá¹ƒgha norğŸ”½secluded, or with offense and in the winter but not in the spring, orğŸ”½in the spring but not in the winter, or both in the winter and in the spring, or

Offenses arising from desire refer to intentionally playing with one's body, touching, speaking harshly, boasting oneself, acting as a matchmaker, and all defiled verbal actions. These are called offenses arising from desire.

Offenses arising from anger refer to groundless accusations, slander, divisive speech, fomenting disputes, expulsion, intentionally causing trouble for someone who has already had enough to eat, expelling from a village, striking with the fist, threatening with the hand, eavesdropping in a secluded place, and so on. These are called offenses arising from anger.
Offenses arising from delusion refer to the deluded mind that considers the world to be permanent or impermanent, and all such views. These are called offenses arising from delusion.
Offenses not arising from desire, anger, or delusion refer to offenses committed by arhats. These are called offenses not arising from desire, anger, or delusion.

There are offenses that are bodily but not verbal: A woman in the same room, a person who has not yet received full ordination staying more than three nights, sleeping on the same bed, sitting on the same bed, eating in different places, eating in a separate group, eating from the same vessel - these are called bodily but not verbal.
There are offenses that are verbal but not bodily: All the verbal offenses - these are called verbal but not bodily.

There are offenses that are both bodily and verbal: Slandering without evidence, reviling, divisive speech, fomenting disputes, expelling, knowingly causing annoyance to one who has eaten enough, expelling from the village, striking with the fist, threatening with the hand, eavesdropping in a secluded place, etc. - these are called bodily and verbal offenses.

Those that are neither bodily nor verbal: Arising from the mind - these are called neither bodily nor verbal.ğŸ”½There are offenses that arise from one's own body but not from another's body: Out of anger, striking one's own body - this is called arising from one's own body but not from another's body.

There are offenses that arise from another's body but not from one's own body: Seeing another person engaging in sexual activity, theft, murder, and concealing it - this is called arising from another's body but not from one's own body.

Those that arise from one's own body and others' bodies refer to sleeping in the same room as a woman, staying more than three nights with one who has not yet received full ordination, sleeping on the same bed, sitting on the same seat, eating in different places, eating in a separate group, and eating from the same vessel. These are called arising from one's own body and others' bodies.

Those that are not from one's own body or others' bodies refer to all the offenses committed by speech, except for the rule of speaking in front of one who has not yet received full ordination. These are called not from one's own body or others' bodies.

Those that arise from one's own mouth but not others' mouths refer to all the offenses committed by speech, except for the rule of speaking in front of one who has not yet received full ordination. These are called arising from one's own mouth but not others' mouths.

Those that arise from others' mouths but not one's own mouths refer to when a bhiká¹£u in the Saá¹ƒgha makes a decision that is not in accordance with the Dharma, does not give consent, and does not express his disagreement but silently passes by. This is called arising from others' mouths but not one's own mouths.

There are offenses that arise from one's own mouth and from the mouths of others means speaking the Dharma in sentences to one who has not yet received full ordination. This is called arising from one's own mouth and from the mouths of others.
There are offenses that do not arise from one's own mouth or from the mouths of others means arising from body and mind. This is called not arising from one's own mouth or from the mouths of others.
There are offenses that take the mind but not the matter means one should ask:
With what mind did one steal?
With what mind did one kill?
With what mind did one touch a woman?
With what mind did one cut living grass?
With what mind did one dig the ground?
This is called taking the mind but not the matter.
There are offenses that take the matter but not the mind means one should not ask:
With what mind did one commit sexual misconduct?
With what mind did one eat at the wrong time?
With what mind did one drink alcohol?
With what mind did one sleep in the same room as a woman or with one who has not received full ordination for more than three nights?
If one commits an offense, one should be dealt with according to the Dharma. This is called taking the matter but not the mind.

There are offenses where the matter is serious but the mind is not serious. A bhiká¹£u eats at the wrong time thinking it is the right time, and commits a pÄyattika offense. This is called the matter is serious but the mind is not serious.ğŸ”½There are offenses where the mind is serious but the matter is not serious. A bhiká¹£u eats at the right time thinking it is the wrong time, and commits a light infringement of the monastic code. This is called the mind is serious but the matter is not serious.

There are offenses where the matter is serious and the mind is also serious. Eating at the wrong time thinking it is the wrong time, one commits a pÄyattika offense. This is called the matter is serious and the mind is also serious.

There are offenses where the matter is light and the mind is also light. The various training rules and deportment are called the matter is light and the mind is also light.ğŸ”½There are offenses that arise from one's own things, not from others' things. A bhiká¹£u steals his own property with a thieving mind and commits a sthÅ«lÄtyaya offense. This is called arising from one's own things, not from others' things.

There are offenses that arise from others' things, not from one's own things. A bhiká¹£u steals others' property with a thieving mind, and for less than five coins it is a sthÅ«lÄtyaya offense, and for five coins or more it is a pÄrÄjika offense. This is called arising from others' things, not from one's own things.

As for offenses arising from one's own property and others' property, if a bhiká¹£u steals with a thieving mind from others' property, less than five coins is a sthÅ«lÄtyaya offense, and more is a pÄrÄjika offense. This is called arising from one's own property and others' property.

As for offenses that are neither one's own property nor others' property, if a bhiká¹£u steals with a thieving mind from property without an owner, it is a saá¹ƒghÄvaÅ›eá¹£a offense. This is called neither one's own property nor others' property.ğŸ”½As for offenses committed in one place but many offenses, if a bhiká¹£u begs for and obtains eight kinds of fine food in one place, and eats each separately, he commits eight pÄyattika offenses. This is called committing many offenses in one place.

As for offenses committed in many places but one offense, if a bhiká¹£u begs in many places and obtains eight kinds of fine food, and eats them all in one sitting, he commits one pÄyattika offense. This is called committing one offense in many places.

If one commits many offenses in many places, a bhiká¹£u begs for and obtains eight kinds of delicious food in eight places, and eats each one, he commits eight pÄyattikas. This is called committing many offenses in many places.
If one commits one offense in one place, one begs for and obtains eight kinds of delicious food in one place, and eats them all at one sitting, this is called committing one offense in one place.

If one commits an offense due to a non-offense, a bhiká¹£u who has no offense repents of his offense and commits a saá¹ƒghÄvaÅ›eá¹£a offense. This is called committing an offense due to a non-offense.
If one commits a non-offense due to an offense, building a small or large dwelling, a woolen blanket, up to three admonitions, this is called committing a non-offense due to an offense.

If one commits an offense due to an offense, when reciting the PrÄtimoká¹£a in the saá¹ƒgha, up to three times, those with offenses should act according to the Dharma, and those without offenses should remain silent.
At that time, those with offenses did not act according to the Dharma, nor did they tell others, nor did they think:
I will do it according to the Dharma with a pure like-minded person.
If one remains silent, one commits a duá¹£ká¹›ta offense. This is called the case of having an offense up to having an offense.

The case of having no offense up to having no offense means not committing an offense by not doing it. This is called the case of having no offense up to having no offense.ğŸ”½The case of a heavy offense leading to a light one means a bhiká¹£u who has committed a pÄyantika offense repenting to one who has been suspended for holding wrong views. This is called the case of a heavy offense leading to a light one.ğŸ”½The case of a light offense leading to a heavy one means a bhiká¹£u who has committed a duá¹£ká¹›ta offense repenting to one who has been suspended for slandering the sÅ«tra. He obtains a pÄyantika offense. This is called the case of a light offense leading to a heavy one.

The case of a heavy offense leading to a heavy one means a bhiká¹£u who has committed a pÄyantika offense repenting to one who has been suspended for slandering the sÅ«tra. He obtains a pÄyantika offense. This is called the case of a heavy offense leading to a heavy one.

As for the light condition leading to the light, if a bhiká¹£u commits a duá¹£ká¹›ta offense and confesses to someone who has not received full ordination, it is not considered done, and he incurs another duá¹£ká¹›ta offense. This is called the light condition leading to the light.

As for the offense at the time of receiving, receiving raw meat, raw grains, gold, silver, elephants, horses, camels, donkeys, cows, sheep, male and female slaves, women, fields, houses, and dwellings, this is called the offense at the time of receiving.
As for the offense at the time of eating, eating separately, eating in different places, eating from the same vessel, and eating impure fruits, this is called the offense at the time of eating.
As for the offense when the matter is accomplished, building small or large dwellings, and all two admonitions, this is called the offense when the matter is accomplished.
As for the offense when not receiving but not when receiving, receiving the kaá¹­hina robe, and abandoning the five precepts:

eating separately, eating in different places, eating apart from the community, not informing about long robes, and staying apart from the robes, this is called the offense when not receiving but not when receiving.

Offenses incurred without permission and those incurred with permission refers to a bhiká¹£u obtaining new robes, not dyeing them in one of the three colors, and using them without making them into a patch. This is called offenses incurred without permission.

Some offenses are committed in the village but not in the wilderness refers to not wearing the saá¹ƒghÄá¹­Ä« robe when entering the village, not wearing the belt when entering the village, not wearing the waist rope, not carrying the alms bowl, not informing and leaving to eat together, and entering the village at the wrong time. This is called offenses committed in the village but not in the wilderness.

Offenses committed in the wilderness but not in the village refers to a bhiká¹£u traveling with thieves, women, or bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s. This is called offenses committed in the wilderness but not in the village.
Offenses committed both in the wilderness and in the village refers to striking with a fist, palm, or knife. This is called offenses committed both in the wilderness and in the village.
Offenses not committed in the wilderness or in the village refers to near the king's gate. This is called offenses not committed in the wilderness or in the village.

There are offenses that are both timely and untimely refers to the eight kinds of eating in a separate assembly, eating in different places, eating from the same vessel, picking and eating, eating delicious food, and eating unpurified fruits. These are called timely and untimely.

There are offenses that are neither timely nor untimely refers to entering the village without announcement at an improper time, eating at an improper time, and instructing the nuns at dusk. These are called neither timely nor untimely.
There are offenses that are both timely and not timely refers to punching with a fist, slapping, and threatening with a knife. These are called both timely and not timely.
There are offenses that are neither timely nor not timely refers to the middle of the night, which is called neither timely nor not timely.

There are offenses that are night but not day refers to sleeping in the same room as a woman, staying with an unordained person for more than three nights, and instructing the nuns at sunset. These are called night but not day.
There are offenses that are day but not night refers to eating in a separate assembly up to eating unpurified fruits. These are called day but not night.
It is both day and night means punching with a fist, slapping with the palm, or threatening with a knife. This is called both day and night.
There are offenses that are neither day nor night means when the dawn appears, this is called neither day nor night.

There are offenses that are committed in a covered place but not in an open place means sleeping in the same room as a woman, staying more than three nights with someone who has not yet received full ordination, sitting in a secluded place where a bed has been prepared for sexual intercourse, or sitting in a secluded place. This is called committed in a covered place but not in an open place.

There are offenses that are committed in an open place but not in a covered place means if the Sangha's bedding is spread out in the open air by oneself or instructed to be spread out, and one leaves without informing anyone, then beyond twenty-five cubits, there is a pÄyattika offense. This is called committed in an open place but not in a covered place.
There are offenses that are committed in both covered and open places means punching with a fist, slapping with the palm, or threatening with a knife.
What are the offenses that are neither committed in a covered place nor in an open place? It means under the eaves of a house.
What are the offenses that are committed while walking but not while standing?

If a bhiká¹£u goes on the road with a woman, a thief, or a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«, and the saá¹ƒgha, preceptor, or ÄcÄrya tell him not to go but he goes anyway, he commits an offense. This is called going but not staying.
What is meant by an offense that is staying but not going?

Staying near a prostitute, staying near a wine seller, staying near a backgammon player, staying near a prisoner, standing in the doorway, and staying even though the saá¹ƒgha, preceptor, or ÄcÄrya tell one not to stay, one commits an offense. This is called staying but not going.
What is meant by an offense that is both going and staying?
Punching with the fist, slapping with the palm, and brandishing a knife.
What is meant by an offense that is neither going nor staying?
When sitting or sleeping.
What is meant by an offense that is standing but not sitting?
Standing near a prostitute, and even though the preceptor or ÄcÄrya tell one not to stand, one stands anyway, one commits an offense.
What is meant by an offense that is sitting but not standing?

Sitting on a bed that exceeds the proper size, a cushion filled with kapok, a skin seat, sitting next to a prostitute, a tavern, a gambling table, or a prisoner, and sitting despite the teacher or preceptor saying Do not sit, one commits an offense.
What is an offense that is both standing and sitting?
Punching with a fist, slapping, or threatening with a knife.
What is an offense that is neither standing nor sitting?
If one is walking or sleeping.
What is an offense that is sitting but not sleeping?
Sitting on a bed that exceeds the proper size, up to sitting despite the teacher or preceptor saying Do not sit, one commits an offense.
What is an offense that is sleeping but not sitting?

Sleeping in the same room as a woman, staying more than three nights with one who has not received the full ordination, a bed that exceeds the proper size, a cushion filled with kapok, or sitting on a skin seat.
What is an offense that is both sitting and sleeping?
Punching with a fist, slapping, or threatening with a knife.
What is an offense that is neither sitting nor sleeping?
When walking or standing.
What is a sin that is sleeping but not walking?
Sleeping with a woman in the same room, even on a skin mat.
What is a sin that is walking but not sleeping?
A bhiká¹£u accompanying a woman or a thief, even if his preceptor or teacher tells him not to go but he goes, commits a sin.
What is a sin that is both sleeping and walking?
Punching with a fist, slapping, or brandishing a knife.
What is a sin that is neither sleeping nor walking?
Sitting or standing.
What is a sin that is in private but not in a large group?
Not abandoning [wrong views] after three admonitions in private.
What is a sin that is in a large group but not in private?
Not abandoning [wrong views] after three admonitions in a large group.
What is a sin that is both in private and in a large group?
Punching with a fist, slapping, or brandishing a knife.
What is a sin that is neither in private nor in a large group?
In the assembly of monks.
What is a sin that is in a large group but not in the assembly?
Not abandoning [wrong views] after three admonitions in a large group.
What is the offense that is in the Sangha but not in a group of many monks?
Not abandoning after three admonishments.
What is the offense that is also in a group of many and in the Sangha?
Punching with a fist, slapping, or brandishing a knife.
What is the offense that is neither in a group of many nor in the Sangha?
Not abandoning after three admonishments in private.
What is the offense that is in the Sangha but not in private?
Not abandoning after three admonishments in the Sangha.
What is the offense that is in private but not in the Sangha?
Not abandoning after three admonishments in private.
What is the offense that is both in the Sangha and in private?
Punching with a fist, slapping, or brandishing a knife.
What is the offense that is neither in the Sangha nor in private?
Not abandoning after three admonishments in a group of many.
What is the offense that is in winter but not in spring?
A bhiká¹£u who has not abandoned his rain retreat bathing robe on the fifteenth day of the eighth month commits a sthÅ«lÄtyaya offense if he does not abandon it on the sixteenth day.
What is the offense that is in spring but not in winter?

If a bhiká¹£u who has accepted the kaá¹­hina robe does not relinquish it by the fifteenth day of the last month of the rainy season, and keeps it until the sixteenth day, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
What is the offense that is both in winter and spring?
Punching with the fist, slapping with the palm, and threatening with a knife.
What is the offense that is neither in winter nor spring?
The time of the rainy season retreat.
What is the offense that is in spring but not in summer?
If a bhiká¹£u who has accepted the kaá¹­hina robe does not relinquish it by the sixteenth day of the last month of the rainy season, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
What is the offense that is in summer but not in spring?
On the sixteenth day of the fourth month, bhiká¹£us should enter the rainy season retreat. If they do not enter the retreat, they commit an offense of wrong conduct.
If they reach the time of the later rainy season retreat and still do not enter the retreat, they commit two offenses of wrong conduct.
What is the offense that is both in spring and summer?
Punching with the fist, slapping with the palm, and threatening with a knife.
What is the offense that is neither in spring nor summer?
That is the time of winter.
What is the offense that is in summer but not in winter?
If one does not observe the two retreat periods, one commits two offenses of wrong conduct.
What is an offense that is winter but not summer?
On the fifteenth day of the eighth month, one should discard the rain-bathing robe but does not, and on the sixteenth day one commits an offense.
What is an offense that is both summer and winter?
Punching with a fist, slapping, and brandishing a knife.
What is an offense that is neither summer nor winter?
This is the spring season, and this is called an offense that is neither summer nor winter.

There are also offenses called not restraining the body, not restraining speech, not restraining body and speech, offenses of the body, offenses of speech, offenses of the body and speech, evil bodily actions, evil verbal actions, evil bodily and verbal actions. These are called offenses.

Those without offenses restrain the body, restrain speech, restrain body and speech, do not commit offenses of the body, do not commit offenses of speech, do not commit offenses of the body and speech, do not engage in evil bodily actions, do not engage in evil verbal actions, do not engage in evil bodily and verbal actions. These are called those without offenses.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
When a vinaya-holding bhiká¹£u is granting absolution to another, he knows when there is an offense and also knows when there is no offense.
He also knows when there is concealment.
He also knows when there is no concealment.
He also knows when there is concealment means: when a bhiká¹£u commits a saá¹ƒghÄvaÅ›eá¹£a offense at dawn, he knows it is an offense but does not have the intention to conceal it;
when he reaches sunrise, he has the intention to conceal it, and when he reaches dawn, this is called one night of concealment.
There is also another kind of concealment: when a bhiká¹£u commits a saá¹ƒghÄvaÅ›eá¹£a offense at dawn, he knows it is an offense but does not have the intention to conceal it;
when he reaches mealtime, he has the intention to conceal it, and when he reaches dawn, this is called one night of concealment.
It is the same for noon, evening, sunset, early night, and middle of the night.
When a bhiká¹£u commits a saá¹ƒghÄvaÅ›eá¹£a offense at dawn, he knows it is an offense but does not have the intention to conceal it;
If he knows it is an offense after the latter part of the night, and has the intention to conceal it, when dawn breaks, this is called concealing for two periods in one night.

There is also another kind of concealment. A bhiká¹£u commits a saá¹ƒghabheda offense at dawn, does not know it is an offense, and when the sun rises he knows it is an offense, but does not have the intention to conceal it;
when it is time for the meal, he has the intention to conceal it, and when dawn breaks, this is called concealing for one night.
The same is true for the middle period, the afternoon, sunset, and the first part of the night.
A bhiká¹£u commits a saá¹ƒghabheda offense at dawn, does not know it is an offense, and when midnight arrives he knows it is an offense, but does not have the intention to conceal it;
when it is the latter part of the night, he has the intention to conceal it, and when dawn breaks, this is called concealing for three periods in one night.

There is also another kind of concealment. A bhiká¹£u commits a saá¹ƒghabheda offense at dawn, does not know it is an offense, and when it is time for the meal he knows it is an offense, but does not have the intention to conceal it;
If, at noon, one forms the intention to conceal [the offense], and when the dawn breaks, this is called one night of concealment at dusk.
The same applies to sunset and the first watch of the night.

If a bhiká¹£u commits a saá¹ƒghabheda offense at dawn, does not know it is an offense, and up to midnight knows it is an offense, but does not form the intention to conceal it, and in the last watch of the night forms the intention to conceal it, and when the dawn breaks, this is called four periods of one night of concealment.
There is also the name of concealment: If a bhiká¹£u commits a saá¹ƒghabheda offense at dawn, knows it is an offense, but is undecided about whether to conceal it or not;
and when the sun rises, he forms the intention to conceal it, and when the dawn breaks, this is called one night of concealment.

In the same way, if at mealtime, midday, dusk, sunset, the first watch of the night, the middle watch of the night, up to the last watch of the night, he forms the intention to conceal [the offense], and when the dawn breaks, this is called two periods of one night of concealment.

There is also a type of concealment. A bhiká¹£u commits a saá¹ƒghabheda offense at dawn, but does not know it is an offense. At sunrise he knows it is an offense, but is unsure whether to conceal it or not.
At mealtime he forms the intention to conceal it, and at dawn the next day, this is called concealing it for one night.
It is the same for noon, dusk, sunset, and the first watch of the night.
A bhiká¹£u commits a saá¹ƒghabheda offense at dawn, but does not know it is an offense. He knows it is an offense at midnight, but is unsure whether to conceal it or not.
At the last watch of the night he forms the intention to conceal it, and at dawn the next day, this is called concealing it for three periods of the night.

There is also a type of concealment. A bhiká¹£u commits a saá¹ƒghabheda offense at dawn, but does not know it is an offense. He knows it is an offense at mealtime, but is unsure whether to conceal it or not.
At noon he forms the intention to conceal it, and at dawn the next day, this is called concealing it for one night.
In the same way, in the afternoon, at sunset, and in the first part of the night, it is also like this.

If a bhiká¹£u commits a saá¹ƒghabheda offense at dawn, but does not know it is an offense, and up to midnight he knows it is an offense, but is still uncertain about whether to conceal it or not, and in the latter part of the night he forms the intention to conceal it, and when dawn breaks, this is called concealing for four periods of the night.
There is also another kind of concealment. If a bhiká¹£u commits a saá¹ƒghabheda offense at dawn, knows it is an offense, and forms the intention to conceal it;
and up to sunrise he forms the intention not to conceal it, and up to the latter part of the night he forms the intention to conceal it, and when dawn breaks, this is called concealing for one night.

There is also another kind of concealment. If a bhiká¹£u commits a saá¹ƒghabheda offense, and if across a wall, across a trench, or in the dark he speaks another's name in a low voice, saying Such-and-such a bhiká¹£u has committed a saá¹ƒghabheda offense, this is not called revealing, and knowingly speaking falsely, one obtains a pÄyattika offense. This is called concealment.

There is also a case where it is not concealed. If one speaks one's own name while separated by a wall, a moat, or in the dark, in a small voice, and commits a saá¹ƒghadisesa offense, it is considered to be confessed.
But if one does it with flattery, one commits a pÄyattika offense.

There is also a case where it is not concealed. If a bhiká¹£u commits a saá¹ƒghadisesa offense, not separated by a wall, a moat, or in the dark, not in a small voice, not speaking of another but speaking one's own name, it is considered not concealed.

There is also a case where it is not concealed. If one has doubts about whether it is an offense or not, doubts about whether it is concealed or not, or doubts about the night, if one confesses, it is considered not concealed.

There is also a case where it is not concealed. If one does not have the intention to conceal, has not yet confessed, has forgotten, has left the monastic life, has entered concentration, or has died, it is considered not concealed.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:

When a vinaya-holding bhiká¹£u is granting absolution to others, he should know what is an offense and what is not an offense, what is concealed and what is not concealed, what is revealed and what is not revealed.
There may be that which is concealed but not revealed, that which is revealed but not concealed, that which is both concealed and revealed, and that which is neither concealed nor revealed.
What is meant by concealed but not revealed?
A bhiká¹£u commits a saá¹ƒghabheda offense, knows it is an offense, conceals it in his mind, and does not tell others about it. This is called concealed but not revealed.
What is meant by revealed but not concealed?
A bhiká¹£u commits a saá¹ƒghabheda offense, knows it is an offense, does not conceal it in his mind, and tells others about it. This is called revealed but not concealed.
What is meant by both concealed and revealed?
A bhiká¹£u commits a saá¹ƒghabheda offense, knows it is an offense, conceals it, and later tells others about it. This is called both concealed and revealed.
What is meant by neither concealed nor revealed?
A bhiká¹£u commits a saá¹ƒgha-vaÅ›eá¹£a offense, knows it is an offense, but does not have a mind to conceal it, and thinks:
Waiting for the time, waiting for the place, waiting for the person, I will act according to the Dharma.
This is called neither concealing nor confessing.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:

When a vinaya bhiká¹£u is granting absolution to others, he should know when an offense should be acknowledged and when it should not, when it should be concealed and when it should not, when it should be confessed and when it should not, and when probation should be granted and when it should not be granted.
What are the cases when it should not be granted?

If there is no offense, it should not be granted. If it is not concealed, it should not be granted. If the offense is uncertain, if the concealment is uncertain, if the night is uncertain, if the person in front does not request it or ask about it, it should not be granted.
What are the cases when it should be granted?

If there is an offense, it should be granted. If it is concealed, it should be granted. If the offense is certain, if the concealment is certain, if the night is certain, if the person in front requests it and asks about it, it should be granted.
Whether it is in accordance with the Dharma or not.
What is meant by not in accordance with the Dharma?
